text:
Okay...all of you wanting to do the skinless boneless chicken and want the sauce to be thicker...here's how:  3/4 cup katsup 3/4 honey 1/2 soy 3-4 cloves garlic 1/2 teaspoon tabasco  cook the mixture on the stove top until boiling and reduce heat.  Pour on top of chicken and bake at 350 for 35-40 minutes...it makes the thick sauce we have been looking for in this recipe...

text:
After learning from my first attempt, I believe I've got the tricks for this recipe. I took tips from myself and other reviews as follows: 1.) season chicken, but watch the salt since the sauce has soy sauce 2.) add 2 tbsp cornstarch and boil sauce on stovetop until thick 3.) cover chicken and cook 45 mins @ 375 4.) uncover and cook for 15 more mins. This came out REALLY good for me. The chicken was tender but not dry and the wings were truly "sticky." The sauce was stuck to them and it was O SO GOOD. You won't be disappointed.

text:
Thank you Sandy!  This is the best baked chicken ever.  I cut everything in half, as I was only cooking one chicken breast (with bone in and skin on) for myself.  I did add a dash of cayenne pepper to tone down the sweetness a bit - to fit my own taste.  This was a trial run - I will serve it for company next week.  Be sure and put a cookie sheet below your baking dish - when this begins to carmelize - it may overflow.  It makes a beautiful piece of chicken - like the photos in cookbooks.  Again, thank you Sandy for sharing.  It is absolutely wonderful. I wish I could give it 6 stars.  P.S.  I forgot to add:  I prepared teh sause in a pot on the stove, brought it to a boil and then turned the fire out - a must for it to carmelize correctly.  Also I turned the chicken breast over after 30 minutes.  If it is too sweet for you, cut back on the honey and add a extra catchup, maybe  little mustard.  Enjoy!

I am logged in under my wife's username.  She gave me permission to post.

This recipe has become a running joke in our household.  My wife is an excellent cook.  In the 7 years we have been married this is the only recipe that I couldn't find anything good to say about.  I believe my candid response was this taste like butt.

Normally I wouldn't be so harsh but it was an involuntary response... it just sort of came out.  She has made many recipes since then and 95% of them are very tasty.  4.99% of them are interesting (she likes to experiment)... and then there is the .01% that is the wings.

Maybe something went terribly awry and this really is a good recipe...  I don't know.  I just couldn't resist writing about our expereience when I saw this recipe in her recipe box.

Sorry to the original poster. My intention is not to be overly critical.  It's just a family legend now. :-)

text:
This was very good. I used a skinless boneless chicken breast and followed the instructions of other reviewers and used  3/4 cup ketchup, 3/4 cup honey, 1/2 cup soy sauce, and 3-4 cloves garlic, cooking the mixture on the stove top until boiling and reducing heat and cooking for 5-10 min. I baked at 350 for about 40 minutes.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe!  I love how simple the ingredients are and the wonderful flavor.  I got this recipe several months ago and I can't count the number of times I have made it.  I have only made it so far with chicken breasts as a main dish.  It will be wonderful with pork chops.  The sauce is wonderful with rice. If you don't like or don't have honey, you can substitute corn syrup (for all or a portion of the honey), it is virtually the same, just without that hint of honey.  I can't imagine not having this recipe anymore.  I will ALWAYS keep this recipe in my baking arsenol.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as stated except I used 3 pounds of skinned boneless chicken breasts (cut into 2 x 2 x 1 inch pieces). I poured the liquid mixture over the chicken and put in the oven for 1 hour (without covering).  The sauce did not caramelize.  I put the pan on the lower oven rack as suggested by others and basted one time during baking.  After one hour my chicken was starting to dry out and burn. I took the chicken out of the oven and removed it from the pan.  The juices were starting to burn along the inside of the pan so I put the sauce in a fresh pan and baked for another 20 minutes.  The liquid did not caramelize.  Taking into consideration how many people have been unable to get the liquid to caramelize, I'm wondering whether an ingredient or an additional step was left out of the receipe. The taste was good but the consistency was like water.  Do wings have considerably less water than other chicken pieces, so that wings are sticky but other pieces are not?  What is the trick?

I lightly seasoned my wings and then poured the thickened mixture on, covered and baked 45 minutes. Then I baked 15 more minutes uncovered basting every 5 with sauce.  Wow.  Thanks for a delicious recipe.

text:
This is quite good. I add some crushed red peppers to the sauce and an extra clove of garlic. Plus, I always just use boneless, skinless chicken breasts. I bake them at 400 for about 10 minutes on each side. Then I slice them into thin slices and throw back in the pan with sauce, toss to coat and stick under the broiler for a couple of minutes. I have noticed that if I use Kikoman Light Soy Sauce, the sauce doesn't want to caramalize as well, so I just stick to the La Choy Light. My picky young kids and husband just love this chicken.

text:
I have used a slight variation of this sauce for years as my barbeque sauce, and it never fails to impress.  I mix 1 1/2 cups ketchup, 1 cup honey, and 1 cup soy sauce, with lots of chopped garlic and a dash of hot sauce to taste.  NO OIL!  You can baste your chicken or ribs as they grill.  The sauce keeps forever in the fridge, and is a huge hit!

text:
OK, so I always read the recipe, then a few reviews and make changes if I feel like it, I know this irks some reviewers, but here's what I did differently... We have VERY strong flavored local honey, and 1 cup would've been overpowering (and expensive!)... So I did a half cup honey and half cup brown sugar, added a good glug of molasses, and I used butter instead of oil.  My thought process for this substitutions was to create more of a "caramel" on the stovetop by simmering (almost boiling!) for about 10 mins.  When I still wanted it thicker, I added a slurry of 1ts cornstarch + 1Tb h2o and continued simmering a few mins more...  This worked beautifully.  Flavor-wise, the only thing I added was the juice of 1/4 lemon and a squeeze of ginger paste which I feel really brightened the flavors.  I have been on a teriyaki/kalbi kick lately and this fit right in!  Will def make again, but only with my changes or it would've been way too thin and liquidy rather than as caramelly as it turned out.  I used boneless thighs this time, and would definitely recommend this but I will surely try it on wings as called for very soon.  Oh, and I like things super saucy so I made the full amt for 1.5# chicken and it was way too much sauce... I refrigerated half... so FYI proportions given are plenty generous.

I tried this recipe because I happened to have all the ingredients on hand.  I mad mine with boneless, skinless chicken breasts that I cut so they wouldn't be as thick.  I mixed the sauce and put it on the stove for about 20 min. and added a little corn starch and water to thicken it up.  Then I poured it over the chicken and baked it on a foil lined cookie sheet for about 20 min.  It came out perfectly.  Very sticky and good.  My husband ate ALL of it.  Thanks Sandy!

I reduced the olive oil to 1 tablespoon and doubled the remaining sauce ingredients, then simmered the mixture on the stove top for about 15 minutes until it thickened. The sauce was  poured over large chunks of boneless skinless chicken and baked for an hour. I served the chicken on a bed of noodles.  It was delicious.  And I already had all of the ingredients on hand.

text:
This is an EXCELLENT recipe!I just use skinless chicken breasts or bone in thighs which are really the best, the bone gives lots of flavor. I did tweak it a bit. I was out of soy sauce and I had A-1 teryaki steak marinade and it made it INCREDIBLE! To that I also added a little bit of orange zest and a little sqeeze of the orange half that I zested and it was so good! I've since made it with soy sauce and it is still really good, but if you happen to try the teriayki marinade instead and add the orange zest and juice you will not be dissapointed! I have made this about 10 times in the past 4 months and shared the recipe with several friends and they all love it.

text:
I found the trick to getting the sauce to caramelize.  Lay a piece of foil just on the top of your baking dish during baking. Turn the chicken about every 20 to 30 minutes to coat with sauce.  This dish requires 1 hour & 45 minutes to 2 hours baking time to complete the caramelization process.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a 9x13 dish of boneless skinless breasts.  I followed the modifications for the sauce (I too wanted a thicker sauce) by the reviewer named Meredith, except I used only 1/4 c. soy sauce and added 1T sugar to cut the wang from using honey (maybe b/c I used raw honey?).  Let the sauce reduce on stovetop while the breasts cook in oven for 15 minutes covered with foil.  Remove chicken from oven, mop up any water from the dish, then pour sauce all over chicken and bake uncovered for 20 minutes.  Very delicious.  If you want an even thicker sauce, reserve half of your sauce rather than pouring over chicken, and continue reducing sauce over stovetop while chicken is baking.

text:
I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts cut up into small pieces to serve over rice.  I found that the sauce caramelized better if I cooked it down seperately and then added it to the chicken.  Since it really doesn't carmelize until the "last minute" on the chicken, there is a danger of over-cooking (which I did and it was my fault...not the recipe's) so be careful out there!  Next time I will add some ginger and hot red pepper to make it more like General Tsao chicken...can't wait!  Thanks Sandy for sharing.

text:
These turned out good. I did not change the sauce but I did change the method I used to prepare them. First I dredged wings in just a bit of flour and refrigerated for 1 hour. I baked the wings for about 20 mins, and then brushed sauce on the chicken baked 20 min. turned and repeated. They really caramelized with this method. Make sure to use foil and spray with cooking spray.

text:
I have been looking for a good General Tso's type chicken, and this sauce was great.  I breaded chunks of chicken breast in cornstarch and seasoning salt and cooked in a large skillet.  Then i cooked and thickened the sauce, adding a dash of ginger and about a 1/2 tsp of red pepper flakes.  I halved the recipe, but added an additional T of ketchup.  Drain chicken on paper towels, place back in skilled, and pour sauce over chicken and simmer to desired consistency.  This came out slightly spicy and delicious; served with white rice and broccoli.  My husbands favorite chinese sauce recipe so far!

text:
Used skinless, boneless chicken breasts, and for two people, used 1-1/2 pounds. Thinking a full recipe of the sauce would be better than cutting those ingredients in half, I put them in a saucepan with 2 T of corn starch and simmered for 15 minutes, then dumped the chicken pieces (2" cubes) into the sauce, then into the baking pan. Baked 45 minutes covered at 375 then 10 minutes uncovered. Next time, will cut the ingredients for the sauce in half as well. Maybe add some pineapple? Served with baked rice, green salad and "No Salad Dressing Salad Dressing" from the Allrecipe site. Very satisfactory meal.

text:
This is delicious, BUT cooking the sauce on top of the stove first is a MUST in order to get the sauce to caramelize in the oven.  You can also substitute your favorite store-bought BBQ sauce for the ketchup for a nice, smoky flavor.   I used 3/4 cup BBQ sauce, 3/4 cup honey, 1/2 cup soy and chopped garlic cooked on the stove for about 15 min.  I have used this over skinless boneless breasts as well as chicken thighs.  Pour the sauce over the chicken and cook 375 for about 45 min. Terrific!!

text:
LOVED IT!  I used Meredith's review advice and made the sauce the way she instructed so it's thicker and plentiful. But I also added 2 tbl. corn starch.  The sauce thickened beautifully!  I used chicken thighs and legs (10 pieces). I sprinkled worcestershire sauce on the chicken and baked it for 45 minutes, while I was making the sauce on the stove top.  Then I drained the juices from the chicken and poured the sauce over all the pieces. I covered it back up and put it in for 15 more minutes. Took the cover off and baked for 20 more minutes.  It was perfect! I served with steamed white rice. There was a lot of extra sauce that everyone drizzled over the rice.  It was delicious! My kids had seconds!

country:
None
text:
These were amazing! I did do a few things differently but stuck true to the recipe otherwise. Like other reviewers I boiled the sauce first to thicken it up, thus ensuring a truly "sticky" chicken wing. (You also want to pat the chicken dry with a paper towel before you add the sauce to it, otherwise it will just slide right off.) Into the sauce I added a dash of sesame oil and a few sprinkles of five-spice powder and onion powder. As this sauce has lots of honey in it you are going to want to cover the pan with foil for the first 45 minutes of baking, or they will surely burn. Since my additions made it a decidedly Asian flavor I topped with toasted sesame seeds and some scallions when they came out of the oven. Sooo fantastic!!! My boyfriend said "Wow" when he saw them. Even without my additions I can tell they will be great and I will make them the original way next time :) Thanks so much Sandy, for this great recipe!!!

userID:
2918010
Display Name:
BJS
isPro:
False

1

107

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As others have stated, this sauce is too runny: adding cornstarch & boiling on the stove until thickened before pouring over the chicken solves the problem.  I made this a third time using large, bone-in, skin-on chicken breasts.  I rubbed with salt, pepper and garlic powder on and under the skin and let them sit while I cooked the sauce. I added another minced garlic clove, upped the ketchup to 1/2 c., lowered the honey to 1/2 c., skipped the olive oil and added a dash of Frank's red hot sauce.  I did not use cornstarch this time, but brought the mixture to boiling, reduced to simmer, then cooked, stirring frequently till the sauce thickened - approx. 10 minutes.  I brushed the underside of the breasts & under the skin with the sauce, placed them in a 13x9 glass baking dish, then poured the remaining sauce over them. I baked them in at 375 for 45 minutes, starting to check for doneness at about 35 minutes. The meat was tender and delicious. I served it with baked vegetable kabobs bought in the grocery produce dept. I seasoned them with olive oil cooking spray, sea salt, freshly ground pepper and oregano, then baked them in a separate pan, along with the chicken for the last 15 minutes.  I turned the kabobs after about 10 minutes. I left them in the oven for another 7 minutes after removing the chicken and letting it rest.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
To make it a little bit more oriental tasting, add some fresh ginger to the marinade.

To caramelize the chicken, two important rules  you must follow:
1- Do not crowd your pan.  This will "sweat" the chicken, which means the chicken juice will come out and make the dish runny.

2- Cook the chicken at room temperature.  This will help the meat to be cooked more uniform.

Threw some boneless, skinlesss chicken thighs in the bottom of the crock pot. Poured the sauce over and cooked for three hours on low. ( I added some onion flakes and a pinch of pepper flakes for some heat)  Pulled the chicken out. text:
Usually I make  recipes exactly as stated before reviewing, but this is the exception.  Tasted the sauce before pouring over the chicken, and it was SOOOO salty from the soy sauce, that I needed to do something, because salt will not come out.
I added some vinegar, I had balsamic on hand, and then some lemon juice,also we like spicy foods, so added cayenne pepper also.  It was much better taste then.  Baked for 20 min then turned up the heat to 450 and returned to oven to crisp up the skin, about 15 min till done.
Was really a wonderful tasting dish, and VERY moist. 
Will make this many more times.

Excellent recipe!  I tweaked it after reading other reviews.  Instead of using 1 cup of honey, I used 1/2 cup of honey and 1/2 cup maple syrup and used the LIGHT soy sauce.  I added all ingredients and cooked in microwave for 3 minutes and I added corn starch (1 tablespoon with just a bit of water) and add to the mix and cooked in microwave for another 2 minutes and then I added this to the chicken.  I first cooked the chicken 30 minutes and then I added the sauce and cooked another 30 minutes, while bastsing it in between and sauce did carmelize.  Perfect!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This would be a good recipe with the addition of some cornstarch to thicken the sauce so that it will carmelize the chicken while baking.  As written, the sauce stays very thin and does not carmelize the meat.  I recommend mixing the sauce together in a saucepan and add in about 2 Tbsp. of cornstarch mixed with some water.  Once this thickens up it can be poured over the chicken to bake.  Also, I prefer using skinless, boneless breasts, thighs and drumsticks.  You'll get more of the sauce flavor if the skin is removed before cooking.

First off, I wouldn't follow the first recommended review that changes the ingredients to make the sauce thicker. I followed that the first few times and the sauce never thickened and had a bitter taste, but was 'okay'. Then one night I was in a hurry and ended up following the exact recipe and the sauce still didn't thicken, but tasted FANTASTIC. it really helped including more honey and less ketchup minus tabasco sauce. Just mixed together and poured over chicken without heating on stove. We can't get enough of that flavor!

text:
I made this dish this past weekend--I cooked the sauce on the stove top like others suggested and used the same ingredients with the following change: added freshly grated ginger to the sauce and omitted the oil and salt and pepper from the sauce. I poured the sauce over the chicken and cooked at 375 degrees for 45 minutes covered with foil and then took the foil off and lowered the temperature to 350 degrees for another 20 minutes. the sauce thickened and carmelized and was oh so sticky. everyone loved it!

kate

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple 6 ingredient recipe that yields superb wings, but the only thing that should be modified is the baking instructions.  I baked them that way and the sauce dripped off leaving only a transparent film on the wings, which wasn't very tasty.  I made it again because I love the taste of the sauce, only this time using a technique I use for baby back ribs.  Let them marinate in the slow cookers 5-6 hours on low, pouring sauce over them every once in a while.  Then switch them to your broiler on an aluminum-foil-covered cookie sheet, and watch them closely, to bake them just enough so they're nice and crisp instead of slimey.  This takes me 5 to 10 minutes.  The flavour is so much more intense thanks to the slow cooker!

This is a definite "go-to" recipe. It's easy but very flavorful! Changes based on other reviews: use 1/4 cup soy sauce (instead of 1/2 cup) & 1/2 cup honey (instead of 1 cup). text:
Really good - a nice change from the usual "buffalo" wings. I omitted the oil, because I felt that the wings would produce enough fat. I also broiled these for a few minutes at the end of the cooking time. I think omitting the oil & broiling helped these get crispy & carmelized (and not soggy). I made this recipe as well as the Candied Garlic Wings recipe from this site on the same night for a "taste test" - and we agreed that this one was better (more flavorful - must be the ketchup!)

text:
I am stretching here with 3 stars...but have to admit, part of the blame lies with me.  I followed others suggestions: cut back on the honey - added more garlic - I basted the chicken every 15 minutes to keep it from burning up.  But I used leg quarters instead of wings...and they looked wonderful (caramel colored) and smelled great too, but the skin was very slimmy - yuck. We had to take the skin off as it was not edible, but in doing so removed the flavor.  I also used thigh pieces and before cooking I removed the skin.  These pieces were much better, but beware of burning.  Without the skin and with the sugar in the honey, they are very likely burn.  And I hope you LOVE the smell of burnt soy and honey, because you'll smell it for hours! =))

Wow, you nailed it! My mom made this all the time while growing up. And we always begged for it. Meredith has it spot on. Except a few things. Double it, add 1 tbs of ginger. No salt! Soy sauce has enough. Here is the key. Grab your party wings and marinate them all day. Then use the remaining marinade to baste the chicken. Yummy!

text:
Like others, I thickened the mixture with water and corn starch with the rest of the ingredients over very low heat for 10 minutes. I used drumsticks and chicken thighs. I covered the dish with aluminum foil which kept it from burning for the first 30 minutes. I had it another 15 minutes without cover, and 2 minutes on broil. I guess because I rotated the meat too often (every 15-20 minutes), i did not get the crust, rather it was semi-liquid thick mass which I did not mind. I will try to cook next time without flipping the meat.

This is delicious...I made a few adjustments though.  I added 2 tbsp brown sugar (cus I was 1/4 cup short on honey) and 1tsp ground ginger (seemed like a good idea).  After baking the leg quarters for an hour the sauce was very thin so I removed the chicken to add 2 tbsp of cornstarch liquid to thicken the sauce. I will definitely make this again...I wonder how this will turn out in the crockpot???

text:
This is a great recipe. It tasted good. I did need to add some cayenne pepper to it to balance out the sweetness a bit. I was also expecting the sauce to thicken but it never did. Beware of how long you cook the chicken. Mine was done in 40 minutes at 375 degrees using legs and thighs. Next time I plan on marinating the chicken overnight then throwing it all in the oven again. This would also be an excellent glaze for grilled meats.

text:
Both myself and my wife LOVE this recipe! Its so simple to make... just mix the sauce... baste the chicken and bake it. Especially delicious with an ice cold beer on the side.... the only tip I would offer that's not in the directions is to flip your wings, breasts or whatever you prefer halfway through cooking. It gets much more of the sauce this way baked onto it, and thus more flavor. Personally I also make 1 1/2 times the sauce it calls for so I have extra to baste the chicken while it cooks. Mmmmmmmmmmmm good!

text:
This was a great recipe! The sauce is very easy to prepare, I followed the recipe exactly, I didn't cook the sauce before and found that it didn't carmelize very well - more of a teriyaki glaze.  However - even without the carmelizing the chicken came out tender (I used boneless skinless breasts as well)and the smell of the chicken baking was wonderful!!  I found a couple of drops of hot sauce was all I needed to kick this recipe up a little - picky fiance loved it, mentioned it would be good sliced in a salad!!

text:
This has got to be one of the best chicken recipes on this site and it's super easy!  I read past reviews that complained about the sauce not carmelizing, so I added corn starch to the sauce and boiled it down, then poured it over the chicken.  I used 1/2 a whole chicken (legs and wings) and I have to say, you NEED to use wings only, it tasted much better than the legs (though the legs weren't bad themselves).  Other than that, followed the recipe to the t.  Thanks.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
So delicious! I too altered it somewhat.  Made the sauce with 3/4 cup each of ketchup and honey. 1/2 cup soy sauce. 2 TBSP veg oil, 3 cloves garlic and a few dashes of red pepper flakes.  Cooked over medium high heat on the stovetop with approx. 1 TBSP corn starch til thick and bubbly.  Poured over halved bone in chicken breasts and baked at 375 til done.  Sauce still got rather thin, so after I removed chicken from oven, I poured the sauce in a small saucepan and reduced on high until thick.  Pour over chicken and YUM!!! Nothing left :-)

This recipe was simply amazing!!! I only used half a cup of honey because that was all i had left and i used thighs.  My entire family loved it. text:
This was a hit, even with my very picky eater (10yr old son).  I added a little extra garlic just because we LOVE garlic, but otherwise did not alter the ingredients.  I followed the suggestion of others and made the sauce on the stovetop first - bringing it to a rolling boil then immediately removing from heat and pouring over the chicken.  I used 2lbs chicken wings and 1lb chicken drumettes (my son prefers those over wings) and baked at 400 degrees in a clear glass dish for about 25-30 mins, turning and basting chicken once half way through, and basting only again about 5 minutes before they were done.  Will DEFINITELY make again, as these were sticky, flavorful, easy, and a hit!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-01-13T20:35:43.003
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
4610128
Display Name:
ren1216
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
120
favoritesCount:
636
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum-O!  I made 6 legs, 6 wings and 2 boneless breasts (which I cut in half).  I wanted to see how each part would turn out.  While pre-baking the legs a little (BF likes them very done), I simmered my sauce on the stove top for about 15 mins, to which I added 2T cornstarch in 2T water.  It thickened up nicely.  Put chicken into a glass 9x13 baking dish; seasoned with salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder, plus a sprinkle of poultry seasoning on the skinless breast meat.  Poured the sauce over all the pieces and tossed it into the oven.  I checked it after about 20 mins and found the sauce was bubbling and getting really thick, which scared me because I knew I  had a while to go, so I covered the dish with foil.  Mistake.  In only about 15 mins, it caused the sauce to become very thin again so I removed the foil.  Next time, I will leave it uncovered and turn it down a little if its cooking too fast.  The house smelled wonderful.  I turned the pieces 3-4 times, was worried the breast meat would dry out, and it probably would have if I hadn't kept turning it.  Baked for the full hour and it all came out perfectly, very tender and delicious!  Loved the flavor.   Thanks for a great new recipe to add to my collection.

text:
Simple, delicious and quick to make.  I made this last night as follows:   I used approximately 3.5 lbs of chicken drumsticks.  I seasoned the chicken on both sides with Onion Powder, Garlic Powder, Black Pepper and Celery Seed.  I also used about 3 Tbs. of Minced Garlic (from the jar) and included about 1 Tbs of the Garlic/Water Juice in the mixture.  I also added 1 Tbs. of Red Pepper Flakes.  I mixed all ingredients together in a pot and boiled for about 7 minutes in an attempt to thicken the sauce based on previous reviews.    I cooked the chicken for approximately 45 minutes covered with aluminum foil, then turned the chicken and cooked for another 30 minutes covered.  I then uncovered, turned once again and let cook for 15 minutes with the cover removed.   The sauce did not come out as thick as I would have liked, as I did not have corn starch on hand.  Next time I will add the corn starch as suggested.  Otherwise, very good.  My kids and hubby liked it as well.

This recipe was DELICIOUS!!!!!  To get the true carmelized effect on the chicken I baked for 50 minutes at 375 degrees and for 10 minute bumped my oven up to "broil" I took the chicken out of the oven and let it sit for a couple minutes before serving. This allowed the sauce to set up a bit and it was OUTSTANDING. The only thing I changed about the recipe was to use boneless skinless chicken breasts versus the wings which I didn't have in my freezer. Overall, this is SUCH a fabulous glaze for chicken. I am going to try it on baked salmon next!  Make it! You will LOOOOVE it!

text:
I made this last night for our family...what a hit!!  The whole family (husband, picky 7YO and 3YO) loved it.  I made approx. 30 wings, served with thai noodles and we ate it all!  I followed other's recommendations and boiled the sauce (3/4 c. honey, 1/2 c lite soy sauce, 1/2 c ketchup, 2 tsp of minced garlic, 1 tsp olive oil whisked together) on the stove and added 1 tbsp of cornstarch.  I cooked the wings covered @ 350 for 45 mins, removed the cover, added the sauce and cooked for an add'l 15-20 mins.  The sauce still was not super thick, but the wings were delicous!!  No one even questioned the sauce and when I suggested that I would work on the sauce next time, they begged me not to change a thing!  LOL!!  Highly recommend this recipe if you're looking for yummy wings.

I made exactly as written, but used a whole chicken bone-in pieces instead of just wings. The pieces with the skin intact, carmelized beautifully making presentation very, very nice for company. I did not cover, did not turn However, I DID baste about every 15 minutes and left in a the oven (turned off) for about a half hour longerm after my chicken was donem while I stir-fried some snow peas & matchstick carrots to go with. Similar, but much less overpowering soy flavor than a Teriyaki. LOVED the chicken cut up over rice with the veggies and sauce all together. Will make again FOR SURE intentionally using more than wings and "all mixed up".

userID:
1389869
Display Name:
SPARKLER8666
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
96
favoritesCount:
141
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this per other reviews and my own taste and it was finger licking good. It may be just as awesome without changes, but I'll tell you what I did in case you want to try. I increased the sauce by using 2/3 cup of low sodium soy/tamari sauce and tripling the catsup and garlic, but I didn't add the oil to the sauce. I used leg quarters with the bones in (4 pounds) and simmered them in the sauce covered on the stovetop for about 25 minutes, turning every few minutes. Then I put the chicken into an oiled baking pan (prettier side down,)  sparingly poured a little of the sauce over top and baked at 425 degrees. While baking I added a corn starch/water mixture to the sauce to thicken it and brought it to a boil for a minute stirring constantly. It didn't need salt.  I added a good dash of cayenne and it needed a little more zip so I added a few tablespoons of rice wine vinegar. It was about time to turn the chicken when this was done (about 10 minutes.)  I turned the chicken and ladled a generous amount of sauce over each peice, but reserved about a cup for later. Baked it another 10 minutes.  Ladled extra sauce over the top of each peice to serve. (Plain brown rice mixed with peas was an excellent side choice.)

text:
I cooked the chicken for the hour as stated but it was WAY over cooked.  I am sure it is because I had smaller wings but it was just gross, very rubbery and tough.  I liked the sauce though.  I think next time I might velvet the chicken before cooking it in the oven.  Velveting is a great Chinese technique to insure moist chicken in case you haven’t heard of it before. You cover the raw chicken with egg whites and corn starch then quickly dip it into boiling water for 60 seconds. Then you go ahead and cook the chicken the way you wanted… grill, oven, sauté, etc. This really does make for that moist Chinese like chicken!

These were really good! Just like teryaki chicken wings! The trick to these is you need to flip them in the sauce, Id say every 10 minutes or so to make sure they are coated in the sauce as the sauce gets thicker and thicker and also to prevent from burning twords the end. text:
My family really liked these wings.  But after reading some of the reviews I made a few changes.
I increased the ketchup to 4 Tablespoons omited the olive oil as the wings have enough fat.  They did not caramelize which most of the reviews mentioned.  When my wings were done I mixed 2 Tablespoons cornstarch and 2 Tablespoons water and mixed with the wings thickened sauce right up also cooked in the bottom of a broiler pan and turned twice during baking.  They turned out great!!!!!!!!!!

text:
This recipe is awesome. I love it! Though if you're watching your cholesterol, you may one to get rid of some of the skin. I didn't use the original recipe but the one from Meredith. I'm going to post it here so y'all don't have to find it: "3/4 cup katsup 3/4 honey 1/2 soy 3-4 cloves garlic 1/2 teaspoon tabasco cook the mixture on the stove top until boiling and reduce heat. Pour on top of chicken and bake at 350 for 35-40 minutes." I suggest you should bake the chicken for 40-50 minutes though. 35 might not be enough. Enjoy!

text:
The flavor is delicious! The only reason I'm only giving 3 stars is because of the adjustments I will make the next time I make this. First, I didn't have wings, so I used chicken breasts. Second, I marinaded the breasts for about 9 hours prior to cooking. Third, next time I will cook for 30 minutes at 430 degrees so the chicken is more tender. Last, I'll stop halfway through cooking to baste the chicken with the juices in the pan to allow for more flavor to stick to the chicken.

I had drumsticks and chicken thighs (bone in and skin on) on hand.  Based on other reviews I doubled the sauce, boiled on stovetop - add 2 tbs cornstarch to thicken, then cover chicken and bake covered for 45 mins and uncovered for 15 more (can increase temp to 400-425).  Delicious!!!  I also ran out of honey so I used molasses and then added some maple syrup to lighten the flavor.

text:
Delicious sauce.  I made it according to modifications of meredith: no oil (I think the chicken adds enough oil, even skinless), extra catsup, more garlic (!) and slightly less honey. I didn't have tabasco so added about a tsp of siraccha sauce. I did boil the sauce but not for long and I would say it didn't thicken. Maybe I need to simmer longer? Cooked it on skinless chicken thighs.  Served over jasmine rice with sauce. Husband and son loved this and inhaled it!  I would say to thicken add a tad of cornstarch before boiling sauce.  My suggestion would be to use lower salt soy sauce but no complaints from my boys.  I will definitely make this again. It is super good and super easy!  Thanks for the recipe.

Display Name:
Kstbn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was perfect and delicious and I did not change the recipe at all!  I did not heat the sauce, or add cornstarch or more ketchup (or any of those suggestions made by others) and these wings were perfect–tender, with a nice sticky-crispy skin. I have the photo to prove it (you can see it on my profile)This recipe is geared for CHICKEN WINGS with bone and skin. You can't expect this recipe written as is to work with boneless, skinless chicken breasts. The skin is what aids in the caramelization and the size of the wings with their bones (I used whole wings, tucking in the tips behind the drumette) is just right for cooking the full hour needed. 

Make sure your oven is 375 degrees. I used an oven thermometer and when I noticed my oven wasn't to temperature, I made adjustments and the caramelization began soon after. I did turn them at the half way point and so allowed a little extra time to account for the heat loss that happens every time you open the door. Have patience and follow the recipe and you won't be disappointed.

text:
I have made this two ways.  With and without the skin.  I am a skin-on guy as it imparts so much flavor to the dish.  In deference to the writer I also tried it skinless.  No comparison.  With the skin is soooo much more tasty.
As to boneless - bone in as chicken wings (mini drumsticks) are meant to be eaten with hands not a knife and fork.  The bone gives a 'handle' with which to eat them.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband LOVED this dish!!  I followed it to the letter (except I forgot to add the olive oil).  I used chicken thighs and two chicken breasts for those that don't eat chicken off the bone.  The thighs were perfectly cooked with the temp and time stated.  The breasts were slightly dry, although the sauce made up for it, but I would reduce time and temp for boneless breasts.  Next time, I will do as other reviewers said which was boil the sauce down to make it thicker or add the cornstarch to thicken.  The sauce was rather thin, but still delicious.  Pour over buttered, garlic noodles or rice and it is fantastic.  And the leftovers???? the glaze just gets stickier and more delicious, if possible. An option would be to chop up some chives or green onion for serving or cut up the chicken into pieces with the sauce as is and serve over a bed of rice. (kind of like the bourbon chicken from the mall, you know, the ones with the samples?)

text:
I made this using the listed ingredients but started with fresh wings skin side down on tin foil on a baking sheet.  I poured the sauce over them baked them 20 minutes then flipped them and baked another 40 minutes.  Best wings I ever made.  I had 4 of them left so I packed them up for my lunch the next day.  Got in the fridge the next morning to get them and noticed the empty dish in the sink.  Just my husband and I living here.  He swears with a smirk that it was not him.

text:
This was basically a teriyaki chicken. I was expecting a much different flavor, so i was dissapointed.  I wish the title or description would have specified this. 
As for the recipe itself , the flavor was well=infused into the chicken. However, the sauce didnt really carmelize perhaps bc i used skinless tenders instead. I would stick with chicken with skin if you really want that caramelization. Theere was a ton of sauce leftover in the pan so you could make rice and pour it over it. IT WILL END UP TASTING LLIKE A CLASSIC TERIYAKI RICE BOWL. 
Bottom line: I liked it, but didnt love it. But, if you are looking for a teriyaki recipe this  will work great for you.

text:
I made these the other night, followed the suggestions of others by adding 3 tbls of flour (i didn't have cornstarch) boiled the sauce before pouring it on the chicken, seasoned the chicken with seasoning salt and garlic power, baked at 375 covered for 45 mins and uncovered for the last 15...the were amazingly good! I would suggest putting them under the broiler for a couple minutes though just to set the sauce better. Also, I only used 1.5 pounds of chicken wings so this definitely would not be enough sauce for 3 pounds of wings.

text:
Oh so good...I used this as a stir fry, I cubed my chicken and cooked in skillet just 1 tbsp olive oil i used cooking spray after that to decrease fat. The sauce I prepared in a pot on stovetop, I doubled recipe cuz my hubby likes saucy stuff! Let it come to a boil then on low stirring with a wisk. Some say this just wont thicken so I tried the cornstarch..some help, I actually sifted in a small amt of flour and that made it perfect. I poured the sauce over chick in skillet to simmer then cut green/red peppers and onions and added at the end. Served over rice, this sauce is so good and versatile, prepare it stovetop and possibilities are endless..thanks for this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic.  I had no problems with it carmelizing like others had.  I put the chicken wings in the oven first with salt, pepper, and garlic powder for 30 minutes.  While that was cooking, I put the sauce together on the stove.  The adjustments I made were minimal and based on what I read from the reviews:  Two tablespoons of cornstarch and water, one teaspoon of red chili flakes, and a few drops of siracha.  I really wanted that sweet/spicy flavor.  Once it was thickened, I poured it on top of the chicken and let it bake for another 15 minutes.  Voila!  It was a hit and I will be making it again!

text:
Not bad. I cooked the sauce (1/2 cup ketchup, heaping tbsp very sweet honey, 1/4 cup soy sauce, 3-4 cloves garlic, 1 tsp spicy hot sauce, 2 dashes cayenne, 1 dash cumin, black pepper) in a pot for 5 minutes, but I should have done it longer. Then placed 3 chicken breasts in a Pyrex, poured sauce on top, cooked in oven for 40 minutes at 350. Be careful to get all the sauce on top of the chicken. Don't waste it in the bottom of the pan.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Another great teriyaki-like recipe but the title didn't promise the "carmelized" part. I still gave it a 5 because when baking with the sauce, it acts like a marinating stage that gave the chicken some flavor. 5-10 minutes before being done, I scooped out some sauce and whisked it with cornstarch then transferred all the sauce and chicken (I used drummettes & wings btw) in large pan and simmered until thickened. I hate the extra step but it's worth it. It's way easier to clean aslo due to using honey than those teriyaki sauces that uses sugar. Update: Second time around, I did not transfer the chicken in a pan but I did scooped out some of the sauce and whisked with cornstarch then poured it back to the baking dish. Well, this will be my go-to teriyaki dish.

text:
Great tasting sauce.  I did add 1T of cornstarch to the soy sauce and heated it on the stove until thickened, then removed from the heat and added the honey.  *hint-it's better if you don't boil honey, as this can change the flavor.*  Poured about 2/3 of the sauce over the wings and baked 45 minutes, then topped with the remaining sauce and baked the final 15 minutes.  Wings were tender, juicy, and lightly caramelized.  Next time, I may try with a slightly higher oven temp to see if they will brown a little more.

text:
Heres how to get a nice crunch! Dry the pieces off, then put them in a bag of flour and shake off any excess flour. Put them on a broiler pan and bake @385. At the halfway point, turn them. When they are finished, toss the wings into the mixture and return them to the pan for about 15 minutes. The will be perfect and crunchy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1188672.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic!  I followed the ingredients exactly except that I didn't add any salt (there is already a whole lot of soy sauce) and I sprinkled in some red pepper flakes.  I boiled the sauce along with some corn starch, then simmered it for about 10 minutes.  I poured the sauce over the chicken (I used 3.5 lbs boneless skinless breasts) and baked it for about 40 minutes, taking it out about every 10 minutes to flip and baste it.  I had also pierced the chicken several times so the flavor would soak through a little bit.  The sauce didn't caramelize - in fact it stayed a little thin even with the corn starch - but the flavor was so delicious it didn't matter what consistency it was.  My husband and I both loved it.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
I loved this recipe and will make it many more times....I used boneless skinless chicken breasts (2 breasts) and cooked for about 35 mins at 375 degrees and the last 30 minutes at 400 degrees, turning the chicken every 15 minutes or so.  Also the sauce didn't really thicken up for me too much so once the chicken was cooked I just poured the sauce into a small saucepan and added a little cornstarch and water and brought the sauce to a boil and stirred until I got the consistency that I wanted....the sauce was so good that I saved the leftover sauce and froze it till the next time I want a plain bland chicken breast..!!! Great recipe!!!

country:
None
text:
Easy and delicious!  My picky kids and the neighbor kids, as well as DH and I, loved it.  I doubled the sauce and kept half back to use at a later date.  I used boneless, skinless chicken breasts cut into large nugget-sized pieces.  I also eliminated the salt; figured the soy sauce and castsup have more than enough.  Simmered the sauce on the stove for about 15 minutes then baked in the oven at 450 for 20 minutes.  The chicken came out perfect but the sauce was still very runny.  We served it over rice.  Everyone loved it, but it would be even more awesome sticky.  I suggest simmering till sauce reaches a honey-like consistency.  Allow at least half an hour for that.  Will definitely make often.  Thank you!

5 stars!  I used skinned turkey thighs, about 2/3 lbs. each.  We're on a sodium restricted diet so I used 1/2 c. low sodium soy sauce and 1/4 cup Bellino Balsamic Vinegar table and basting sauce which has zero sodium.  I will cut back on the honey next time.  The glaze made a delicious gravy to pour on the brown rice I made to serve with the turkey.  I also basted the thighs about 4 times during baking them for a little over an hour; they were very tender and tasty.

Very very easy recipe. Certainly a big hit with my family.   If you want to get the deep color try basting it before its done and then again when you take it out while its still hot.   If you dont have enough honey you can substitute brown sugar.   1 cup of honey = 1 & 1/4 cup of brown sugar.

text:
I am SOO excited - I'm in shock by how much my dad enjoyed this!!! He's always easy to please but he went on and on and on about how amazing this was!  Here's what I did: mixed 3/4 cup ketchup, 3/4 cup honey, 1/2 cup soy sauce, and some minced garlic; cooked the mixture on the stove top until boiling and reduced heat. Put carrots and 3 bone in skinless chicken breasts in my crock pot, poured the sauce over top, let cook on high for 1 hr, then on low for another 3.5-4 hrs, then on high for the last hour and added broccoli and cauliflower during the last hour. Served with chicken fried rice!

text:
This is FREAKING AWESOME. The flavor was perfect and I actually scaled this down to one serving for some left over wings. After devouring my last wing, I was wishing I had more to nibble on. My modifications to the recipe include the following: 1)My wings were lightly preseasoned with S&P. 2)I added brown mustard and chinese spicy mustard to the mixture. 3) I then added a little curry and pepper to the chicken and then mix the sauce. I placed the chicken in the over and cook to done. Then I broiled and flipped continuously. I had no problem with the chicken caramelizing without heating the sauce first. Next, time I may let it broil just a tad longer to cook the skin.   The taste of this recipe is amazing. I was able to take advantage of low sodium soy sauce, no sugar added ketchup, and avoid a lot of junk served in processed/fast food restaurants. This is an all-star recipe to add to my building arsenal

text:
very good. i took bits and pieces of advice from several viewers: 1.) boiled sauce over stove top + cornstarch 2.) used more garlic and ketchup, added red pepper flakes 3.) baked covered @ 375 for 20 min. in 9 x 11 pan 4.) baked uncovered for 20 more min. 5.) broiled 5 min on each side for last 10 min in broiler pan. 6.) also flipped and basted wings about 3-4 times. it had a really good glaze and nice color :)

text:
I couldn't go 1 cup of honey--too sweet just thinking about it!  I used 3/4 cup honey, 1/4 cup ketchup, 1/2 cup lower salt soy sauce and 1 heaping T. minced garlic.  I brushed the sauce on skinless, boneless chicken breasts.  I baked them in the oven and finished them on the grill.  I added 1 T. cornstarch and 2 T. cold water to the remaining sauce and cooked it in the microwave 2 minutes.  Yummmy!  I wish I had chicken wings rather than chicken breasts.  Next time, definitely chicken wings!

text:
I made this recipe using boneless/skinless chicken breasts. I made the sauce as written, but heated it on the stove with a TBS of cornstarch mixed in for thickening. I browned my chicken breasts first and cooked them at 350 in the oven for 40 minutes, turning once. Everyone liked the sauce on the chicken, but I think next time I will cover the chicken and perhaps reduce cooking time to 30 minutes. The chicken was a bit dry, but dipping it in the sauce took care of that. Overall, this is a great recipe, easy to assemble ingredients, quick prep, and makes a great dinner. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Wonderful! I made some adjustments also. 1/2 cup of ketchup, 1/2 soy sauce, 1/4 teaspoon of ginger, 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg, about 1/2 cup of honey, 1 tablespoon of brown suger, 3 to 4 teaspoon of white suger, 1 teaspoon of lea and perrinsworchestershire sauce,  tablespoon of garlic powder(may neet to add more) and 1 teaspoon of texas pete hot sauce.  I cook that on the stove for about 5 minutes and poured over the chicken during the last 15 to minutes of oooking.  I seasoned the chicken(legs and thighs) with pepper, accent, chili powder, and paprika. I let that back for about 30 mintues.  Two rules to good cooking always taste as you go along specailly with sauces so you can make adjustments and always use tongs!

I made these last night for dinner with some drumsticks I had in the fridge.  The only change I made to the recipe was to add about 2 tbs of cider vinegar. I definately have no complaints with the ease of it- I'm sure I'll be making it again.

userID:
715
Display Name:
angus

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe gets four stars because it is a good recipe on its own, but better as a starting point for making delicious wings and other pieces of chicken.  I de-skin drumsticks, breasts, thighs, you name it for this recipe.  For superbowl, I trimmed the fat from dozens of boneless thighs, cut them into smaller pieces and prepared them using this as a base recipe. They were a huge hit.  I marinated them overnight in some soy/ketchup them made lots of sauce the next morning for the actual baking.  I also include at least a few drops of some hot sauce...even if you don't like spicy at all, this adds a kick of flavor.  I think this recipe should include a step for basting and turning, which I have found, by trial and error, to be essential.  The upshot:  Turn and baste once in the middle of baking, then again when they are almost done.  If needed for extra sticking power, turn the broiler on for a few minutes after basting just before you are ready to take them out of the oven. Get lots of napkins and enjoy.

I have made this recipe several times, each time changing it a bit.  I made it per instructions this time and it was great - a definate keeper. userID:
615195
Display Name:
Aspiring Chef Rita
isPro:

followersCount:
52

744
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/146.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has good flavor - but I used the quick methods others used because too many people said it won't carmelize after spending so much time cooking.  I ended up using chicken breasts, substituting dark soy sauce and adding extra garlic, red pepper flakes and ginger - then marinated chicken for 2 hrs. I put it in foil lined pan - then I boiled that marinate -like others - adding some corn starch/water mixture.  Poured that over the chicken (reserving some to pour over rice) - cooked it at 400 degrees for 10 min. each side. Everyone enjoyed it and liked the sauce on the rice - I served it with Asian style green beans.  Will make it again since it's easy and have the items on hand.

This chicken is absolutely wonderful !!! I made a few improvitions: I used boneless skinless chicken breast, and I cooked the sauce for about 10 min. on the stove top after reading the reviews. But anyway, the chicken carmelized beautifully and taste great ! Thanks for this terrific recipe Sandy, will definately make again.

text:
this is great and really easy.  I have tried it covered and uncovered.  I prefer it covered for all except the last 15 minutes of cooking.  That lets the sauce thicken, but if you leave it uncovered the whole time the sauce seems to scorch and give it a smokey or even "burnt" taste.  Great recipe.

This was delicious the meat was so tender but I made a few adjustments.  I cut off the wing tips and used 1/2 the soy then added 2 tablespoons honey bbq sauce.  After mixing ingredients in bowl I put all but 1/4 cup in a pot.  The 1/4 cup I added about 2 tablespoons cornstarch to that and whisked when no more lumps and it to the pot, heat untill bubbly and thick then add over wings.  They were really wonderful thank you!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had a difficult time deciding on a rating for this dish.  The flavor was delicious but, I found the sauce to be runny and not thickened.  I knew that the chicken would burn if I didn't cover it so I started it out skin side down, covered with foil.  At 30 minutes, I turned the chicken pieces over.  At 45 minutes, I uncovered it.  At the end, I basted everything with the watery sauce because the pieces looked dry on top.  The skin did not get crispy (probably because it was covered).  But, the flavor was very good and the chicken was moist.  It would make delicious chicken wings if I could figure out how to get thickened sauce without burnt chicken. Update: Have tried again. I recalled from making ribs that when you want something to caramelize, you need to use a shallow pan.  So, I made the wings in a jelly roll pan covered with foil.  Once again, the taste was good, but the sauce still did not fully caramelize.  It did get thicker than last time.  Won't make again as there are other easier, better recipes for sticky wings.

text:
AWESOME! First, I made the chicken exactly as directed THEN I read a few reviews. The chicken was in the oven cooking away (about 15 minutes) when I took it out, drained the juices into a small pot, and put the chicken back in the oven all alone. Into the marinade, I stirred the corn starch (mixed with a little water) to thicken it. My hubby likes spice more than me but I added a teaspoon of hot sauce just cause I love him. THEN, I pulled out the chicken, spooned on the thickened sauce and put it back into the oven for
another 15 minutes to make sure it was fully cooked. SOOOO GOOD! Ate more than I should have. *smile*

This was great!  It was borderline over-salty though.  I didn't have low sodium soy sauce, so that would probably do it.  I adjusted the sauce like a lot of reviewers did by adding more ketchup and less honey.  Cornstarch would've been helpful too.
I highly recommend adding a chopped up sweet potato under the chicken while it bakes!  I also had some leftover caramelized onions that I threw in too, which was awesome.  I served it all over some quinoa and it was just fantastic!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I seasoned 30pcs chicken wings with salt and pepper, prepared the sauce to the letter, added the chicken and let it marinate for an hour. Poured everything into a baking dish and baked it in a preheated oven at 375F COVERED with foil for 45mins (as suggested by some reviews) took off the foil and baked it for an additional 20mins. Sauce did thicken a bit and the wings had charred parts (no complaints about it). Served it with rice. No left overs&requests for more equals a success in my books.

I followed the altered recipe for boneless skinless and it was delicious! I also added 2 Tbsp of corn starch.  Boiled on stove for 5 - 10 min then poured over chicken, covered and baked 40 min, uncovered for last 15 min, basting every 5 min for the last 15 min.

text:
I have tried this with breast and wings.  The bottom line for me is that if you are going to make it, use the wings as suggested.  I have tried cooking the glaze on the stove top as recommended by other reviewers and I've just poured it over the chicken as written...  both yielded the same results with the wings caramelizing just a bit better.  I will continue to make this but I will certainly use wings and skip the stove top on the glaze.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe, however I did not have the results that I wanted initially. I am not sure if I did something wrong. But I did not get a thick gooey sauce after baking the chicken in the oven. Instead the sauce was runny and watery. I meant to use the corn starch (as suggested) to thicken up the sauce but I was out of it. In order to save the recipe I placed the sauce and the chicken in a saucepan on the stovetop and simmered it on med-hi letting the sauce thicken for 5-10 minutes. It was phenomenal after that!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-10-25T05:50:00.007
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
591569
Display Name:
Beth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
186
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/196893.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe kicks butt!  These wings were so awesome.  I had 12 wings, split in two.  I doubled the olive oil & ketchup and instead of the garlic clove, added 1 tsp each of garlic powder & onion powder.  I marinaded the wings in about 1/2 of the sauce for 8 hrs, then I dumped the wings & marinade on a parchment lined baking sheet.  After 15-20 min. in the oven, I poured the rest of the sauce over the wings & gave them a little toss to coat.  I let them bake, turning occasionally for about 45-50 min & then turned the oven off & let them sit in the oven for the last 10 min.  My kids thought I was the best mom on the planet (like there was any doubt).  Next time I think I'll add more garlic though but these were truly delicious, the meat fell off the bone & the sauce was a caramelly, gooey bit of heaven. Thanks Sandy - you rock!

text:
Absolutely delicious! I cooked the sauce on the stovetop beforehand to thicken it up (added a little cornstarch/water). Cut up a whole chicken, cooked it 20 mins then turned over and cooked another 20-30 mins. Basted with sauce several times during cooking. Meanwhile cooked a pot of rice and when chicken was done, removed skin, cut up chicken and made perfect terikayi rice bowls. Would have been perfect with green onions if I had them. Husband LOVED and friend who showed up unanncounced devoured! A Keeper! Thanks!

text:
First I would suggest if you want "sticky" chicken, then follow other reviewers suggestions for thicker sauce.  If you follow the recipe as it is, only one side will be sticky.  The sauce just rolled off my drumsticks as I poured it on.  Second, Even though I put down tin foil, the sauce stuck badly to my pan.  I was not happy about that.  The smell after about 20 minutes was not pleasant. Although it tasted fine (my husband actually quite enjoyed it) it was definitly not a keeper in my opinion.

text:
Very good.  Taking the advice of one of the reviewers on the main page, I wanted to use 3/4c honey and ketchup.  However, when I started assembling everything, I realized we were almost out out of ketchup!  I only had about 1/4c, so I added 1/2c BBQ sauce to it.  Boiled that, along with the honey, soy sauce, garlic, and pepper, on the stove for a few minutes and poured it over chicken wings.  I had way more than enough sauce and ended up with about 1/4c leftover.  My wings were done after about 45 minutes, however, the sauce wasn't quite caramelized like I hoped.  Next time I may try turning the broiler on for a few minutes after the wings are nearly done to finish the sauce off.  Overall, very good recipe.

country:
None
text:
I make this all the time. I add a little more spices to kick it up a notch or two. I like to add 2 tsp of finely mince ginger and 2 tsp of finely minced lemon grass together. Instead of 1/2 cup of soy sauce I would use 1/4 cup and 1/4 cup of hoison sauce. It makes this a more southeast Asian dish with the garlic, ginger and lemon grass. I also chop up scallions and top it on the dish with some roughly ground black peppers. Makes it look really attractive and adds some extra taste to it.You can find more fresh and affordable lemongrass at any asian supermarket. You can find Hoison and ginger pretty much any where now.

country:
None
text:
I used this on two boneless, skinless chicken breasts. I followed the sauce measurements exactly as the recipe called for. I first boiled it in a sauce pan and added 2 tbsp cornstarch to help thicken it up a bit. That helped. Then I poured the sauce over the chicken and cooked it at 375 until the internal temperature reached the "poultry" line. I think that's 180 degrees. The sauce didn't caramelize on the chicken. It was more like a very thick dipping sauce. But it did taste absolutely fantastic and I'll make this again in the future. Next time though, I'll use chicken wings and see how that turns out.

text:
I didn't read any of the reviews before I made this, so like many others, my sauce didn't caramelize. It was basically the consistency of water. So, after baking, I put the sauce in a pot on the stove and boiled with a little cornstarch mixed with water to thicken it up. I tossed the wings with the sauce and it tasted fantastic. I will make again following suggestions of other reviewers and thicken the sauce beforehand.

text:
Yum, I'll be making this again for sure! I did modify by: cutting back on the honey; added about 1 tsp of ground ginger, an extra clove of minced garlic, a little orange juice, about 1 tablespoon of brown sugar and a teaspoon of sesame oil. I only wish I had added some crushed red pepper. The chicken was falling off the bone and the sauce was wonderful. Warning - the sauce doesn't taste that good by itself (i.e., dipping your finger in before adding to the chicken) but it's really really good once it's baked onto the chicken.   I also basted the wings every 10-15 min or so during cooking and cooked at 400 uncovered the entire time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/926498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very tasty. I even tried a wing myself and agreed it was tasty (and usually I won't touch bone-in meat). The only things I changed were that I ran out of honey and had to make up the difference (around 1/4 c.) with orange marmalade. (Well, it was that or strawberry preserves...which probably would have been good too.) I also added around 3/4c. of chopped green onions to the sauce halfway through, and 1/4 c. dehydrated onions to the sauce right from the start. (We like onions...) The only thing I did NOT like about this recipe was the overwhelming flavor of soy sauce in the drippings. Since I served the drippings over brown rice, and will again, I'll need to do something about that soy sauce...think I'll just experiment with reducing the overall amount of soy sauce til I get it perfect. Thanks for a wonderful recipe! (P.S. I did use wings with skin, my sauce did caramelize, but if you are expecting it to turn into something thick and sticky on bottom you'll burn it..the chicken leaks grease which will liquefy the juice! The caramelization takes place ON the chicken skin, and that worked perfectly.)

text:
I enjoyed the chicken very much, although i did follow some of the other reviews and cooked the sauce over the stove with a tablespoon of cornstarch to make it thicker. I then poured the sauce over the chicken and wrapped it tightly in foil so that it would boil the chicken in the sauce to make it more tender. i baked it for about 45 minutes wrapped up tight and then 15 more minutes opened up. This is also ideal if you don't want to make too much of a mess.

Display Name:
KIMMBAH
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/260726.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved the recipe to cook 3 skinless breasts.  I only had about 1/4 cup of honey and made up the other 1/4+ cup with Karo light corn syrup (its what I had on hand).  I mixed all ingredients and brought to a boil in a cast iron skillet.  I added 1 tablespoon of cornstarch dissolved in 3 tablespoons cold water to the mixture and boiled about 2 minutes.  I added my 3 breasts and popped the skillet in the oven.  I set the timer for 15 minutes and brushed the sauce; I set the timer again for 15 minutes and brushed again.  The breasts were about done (145 degrees) at this point so I put back in the oven for another 6-7 minutes and it was perfect.  I cooked at 375 by the way.

text:
My family loved this!  I made the sauce and simmered cut up chicken breasts in it on the stovetop for 20-30 minutes. I did follow suggestions and add a couple of tablespoons of cornstarch mixed in some water to thicken it up a little.  Served it over brown rice cooked in chicken broth.  My husband declared it one of his favorites now!  I think next time I will use a little less honey, as it was very sweet, but it's great as is.
Update:  Adding cut-up broccoli (frozen or fresh) when the chicken is simmering and cooking it in the sauce is wonderful also.  Sometimes I add a little red pepper flakes to add some heat.

2083849
Display Name:
Brook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/243505.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was tasty, but I agree with some of the other reviewers that it didn't really carmelize.  (Plus, the sauce nearly ruined the glass baking dish we cooked it in.  If you bake it, either use a disposable roasting pan or line the baking dish with foil!!!)  I halved the chicken so I would have double the sauce to pour over rice.  To thicken the sauce I used some of the reviewer suggestions and added 2 tbs cornstarch and brought it to a boil for a few minutes.  Half of it I poured over the chicken to bake and the extra sauce I left on the stove simmering on low.  The sauce in the pan with the chicken came out MUCH thinner than the sauce I left on the stove top, which had a nice syrupy consistency.  Since it didn't carmelize, I think this recipe would be faster and easier, and just as good, if you cooked the chicken and sauce in a frying pan on top of the stove.  However, I did love this simple but delicious sauce; I am always looking for new ways to dress up plain old chicken!  To me it tasted like something you'd get at a chinese restaurant.

My family liked this dish!  Tastes like a good teriyaki sauce and it's very easy to make. text:
This was SOOOO good!!  When my extremely picky family talks about when I'm fixing this dish again as they are eating 2nds and 3rds, I know it's a hit :) The sauce was DELICIOUS! But it does make a ton....I was worried it wouldn't be enough because I used 4-5 lbs. of legs and thighs....we had PLENTY.  After the chicken was done, I transferred it to a platter, poured the sauce in a small saucepan and thickened with a little cornstarch.  We poured it over our chicken and wished that I'd fixed rice to pour the sauce over too.  YUM YUM!  Will make again and again!  I will probably follow other reviewers suggestions next time, and remove some sauce with a turkey baster to allow the sauce to carmelize and thicken more while baking.

awesome! i halved the recipie in half because i was making it for just my boyfriend and myself. i used 4 drumsticks, added 2 tsp of brown sugar and a little bit of montreal spicy seasoning. i lightly coated them in the sauce first and used the rest of the marinade as a baste. i basted every 15-20 mins and it carmelized BEAUTIFULLY. they were so sticky and awesome, i bet they'd be even better on a grill :)

text:
With so many saying the sauce doesnt carmelize, I did the recipe differently. My sauce alterations: doubled the garlic, used about 3/4 cup honey, and about 1/3-maybe 1/4-cup soy sauce (teriyaki sounds interesting...I'll have to try it). Marinated cubed chicken for about 2 hrs in the sauce. I cubed potatoes and put them in an oven bag, then poured the marinated chicken over this evenly. Baked at 350 for 45 min- 1 hr. When it finished I mixed in whole green beans that I cooked on the side. This was an awesome oven-made stir-fry! I cant recommend it enough!!

text:
OK, I'm giving this recipe 3 stars because I think it has pretty good potential. As is, I personally think its WAY too sweet(and I love sweet sauces and marinades). I might try this again using 1/2 cup honey (which I think would be more than enough) and 1/2 cup orange juice (hubbies suggestion). Definitely a kid pleaser however, my 10 and 6 yr old devoured them. My husband and I ate them, but both agreed that it's just way to sweet.  I saw alot of reviews that said the sauce didn't carmalize- not ALL the sauce is going to carmalize, only the sauce that sticks to the wings will carmalize and that they did very nicely!

city:

country:

text:
This was a good tasting meal, but there was something missing.  It had an Asian taste, so I served it with brown rice.  I did make the sauce in a saucepan, thickened with a little cornstarch mixture, and then pour it over the chicken.  The chicken produces so much liquid, though, that the "sticky" sauce becomes watery and slides right off the chicken.  I ended up, half way through the baking, taking the chicken, putting it on a broiler pan, and basting it often with the sticky sauce.  I wish I would have done this the entire baking time to ensure the chicken had plenty of this good tasting sauce.  (NOTE:  I used boneless, skinless breast.)

text:
We really liked this recipe a lot.  Usually recipes fall into either kid recipes or adult recipes around our house.  So I love it when we find something the whole family likes.  I used boneless skinless breasts that I cut up into strips.  Mine turned out a little on the dry side, but thats because I could see the sauce was starting to carmelize, and I decided to leave it in long enough for that to happen.  Maybe I will cut my strips just a little larger next time, as we dont really like wings all that much.  Delicious flavor though, and very very easy.

text:
All of the recipes I have found on this website have been 5-star (in my own opinion, and I also look for those who are rated as such). However, this recipe was okay, but nothing special. I used boneless skinless breasts, and the sauce mixture burned on the bottom of the pan just like another reviewer. The taste was fine, but nothing out of the ordinary although the chicken was dried out (and I basted it every 10 min). Didn't carmelize either. Would have turned out the same if I just cooked the chicken breast in my George Forman and drizzled sauce over it. Don't think I'll try this one again.

text:
I didn't have a problem with the chicken caramelizing at all.  I did use the sauce as a marinade overnight. (What could it hurt?) Then I placed the wings on a foiled lined cookie sheet with no extra sauce, baked at 350 for about 40 minutes, turned them over and baked at 275 for another 25 or so.  Because I used the sauce as a marinade in raw chicken, I did not use the it for any other purpose.  The wings caramelized beautifully!  The 4 star rating designates a not to exciting recipe.  Probably won't make it again as there are sooooo many recipes and so little time!

Made this tonight and hubby gave ut 5 stars.  I did not reduce the sauce as other reviewers suggested.  I cooked the chicken for an hour and 15 monutes and then let it sit outside the oven for 15 minutes until we were ready to eat. The sauce was not as thick as a barbeque sauce but has enough body to stick to the chicken when I spooned it over.  I also basted the chicken with the sauce 3 times while it cooked.

text:
It's not often I find a new chicken recipe that is really different AND excellent. I made this using hindquarters and instead of 1 cup of honey, I used 1/2 cup and then added 1/2 of an Asian sweet/hot sauce. Left out the salt because of the amount of soy sauce. 
My only complaint,and it is not really with the recipe, is that the carmelized sauce stuck so badly on one of the pans I used that I had to soak it overnight and still scrape and soak some more. The strange thing is that the teflon one stuck so badly, but the stainless steel didn't nearly as much, so I suggest using that if you have it.

text:
I made this recipe a second time last night and I was able to get a caramelized sauce.
I used a shallow baking pan instead of a dish.  I lined the bottom of the pan for easy clean up.
I also baste the wings occassionally.  The sauce caramelized after 45 min.  It was sticky and yummy.  
One word of caution, remove the wings from alluminum lining before it is cooled, it sticks.
I will make this again.

text:
This is a GREAT recipe! It incorporates all my favorite tastes (sweet, tangy, sticky) into one dish! Tip: For optimum caramelization, baste and turn the chicken every so often during baking.  This exposes the sauce more evenly to the heat. Also make sure you have enough honey --- it's the ingredient that causes the dish to caramelize!

HOWEVER, I then took the leftovers the next night, shredded the chicken, added corn starch to the sauce, added veggies and sauteed it and ate it over brown rice.  Delicious!  I would make this as a stir fry again next time, or try it with the wings, as thighs were too big and the flavor didn't seep into the meat.

My go to recipe that is also great on ribs. I use bbq sauce instead of ketchup, cook sauce on stovetop first with 1 tsp corn starch until thick. You can kick this up a notch by generously adding a dry rub before you put in oven..broil on low for 
last two minutes to lock in flavor..absoutely delicious!

text:
This was really good! I followed some of the advise of other reviewers and first seasoned my chicken lightly.
I used bone in chicken drumsticks and thighs.
I then cooked the sauce in a small pan on the stove top and added 2 tbsp of cornstarch to thicken. 
I poured the sauce over the chicken and baked as directed.
I turned up the oven to 500 at the end for about 7 min to really get that caramelized sticky texture.
Next time I will try using boneless skinless chicken thighs or breast.
Thanks for this recipe!!!

userID:
17023453
Display Name:
Heather Garcia
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2968398.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  I did borrow tips from other reviewers.  

Heat the sauce on the stove and add 2 tablespoons of cornstarch.  I tweak the sauce recipe, adding less soy sauce, some water and a tiny bit of mustard.  I play with the sauce until I like the taste!  

Season the chicken wings before covering in sauce. I used a chicken rub.  

One thing that is so important is making sure the chicken is completely thawed and paper towel dried.  Too much moisture will make the sauce slide right off and then you’ll end up with a watery puddle of sauce.  

Let it bake for 20 minutes then baste with any fallen sauce.  Check back at 40 minutes and rebaste if needed, and do this again right before the hour mark.   

The result is super sticky wings that are absolutely delicious!
Review:

5

userID:
11256561
Display Name:
Becky H
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7702324.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor on this was great! I made it with chicken legs instead of wings. One issue I have had making this, as well as other similar recipes is that they say to bake it until the sauce is carmelized. Mine never carmelizes. I haven't added any extra liquid, in fact per the instruction of a chef I took a class from I did not even rinse the chicken first so there is no additional liquid at all, but still I end up with a very watery liquid in the pan after cooking. And that was after nearly 2 hours in the oven! Oven was thoroughly preheated, recipe was followed exactly. 

I ended up cooking down the liquid on the stove top for a while to thicken it a little, then pouring a small amount over it. Next time though I think I will cook it down longer and maybe add some corn starch to aid in thickening it to give it a much better glazed appearance.

Garnished with some chopped green onions and toasted sesame seeds as another reviewer did and it looked great! Went over well at a neighborhood get together. 

By the way, I was terrified I ruined the recipe by adding about 3/4 tsp of salt in addition to the soy, but that was just the right amount. I also added just a hint of ginger to it. Yum!!!

Great recipe as is or change to your own liking. Really hard to go wrong with this recipe. I personally buy the boneless thighs on sale @ warehouse store for a couple bucks a lb.This recipe is enough sauce for over 5lbs of chicken. I like to cook the sauce as suggested by another reviewer  to thicken it and the last time I made it I threw in some spicy orange marmalade which really tasted spectacular. Have fun with this recipe, you can go sweeter, spicier, whatever you like and turn this recipe into quite a few recipe options.  This is definitely a keeper.

I baked them at 400 for like 25 minutes and they were cooked perfectly. Use a disposable pan for easy clean up (sauce was really sticky and started to burn to the edges of my nonstick pan).

text:
I did this Merideth's way for chicken breasts and it was awesome...3/4 cup katsup, 3/4 cup honey, 1/2 cup soy, 3-4 cloves garlic, 1/2 teaspoon sriracha, cook the mixture on the stove top until boiling and reduce heat. Pour on top of chicken and bake at 350 for 35-40 minutes..

This was a great recipe. I used the drumstick chicken wings (3 packs). I did cook the sauce on the stovetop and added a mix of cornstarch & water after the sauce started boil( note: only use 1 tbsp of olive oil) Cooked the sauce until it starts thicken and pour over wings. Cook 30 min covered turn, another 30 min. covered and 20 min. uncovered on foiled lined deep baking sheet. Honestly they were best wings I've ever had, better than any restaurant. My dad loved them and he is a wing pro.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only change I made was to add 1 1/2 tsp cornstarch after it had cooked for 45 minutes and wasn't thickening as much as I would have liked.  I poured off the sauce into a saucepan, added the cornstarch mixed with about 1 tablespoon of water, cooked it on the stove for 3-4 minutes and then poured it over the chicken and returned it to the oven for another 20 minutes or so.  Served it over rice.  Both hubby and I loved it.  He said next time he would have me separate it into two dishes so he could add a little heat in the form of some red pepper flakes to his but had no problem eating it the way it was.  Have added it to the "keeper" recipe book.  I did use boneless breasts this time but will definitely use it for wings the next time we make them.
