country:
None
text:
Here's the thing they don't tell you: You have to BASTE the chicken with the sauce several times during the cooking process.  Then you will get the gorgeous dark color and tasty coating.  I also used boneless/skinless thighs instead of wings.  You actually get some meat that way.  (What is this obsession with wings anyway???) Also, I turned the heat up to 400* the last 10 minutes to increase caramelization.  So good! If you want to "kick it up a notch," add the zest and juice of an orange to the sauce.. and maybe a little more garlic.

text:
Loved it! I followed some of the suggestions and boiled the sauce for 5-10 minutes on the stove top to caramelize it. It was perfect!! I liked the 3/4 ratio of ketchup, honey, 1/2 cup of soy sauce( I used the lower salt version) and two tbsps olive oil. I added seasoning to the sauce before boiling. Baked the chicken 30-40 minutes. I did cover it with foil for the first 15 then kept basting it there after. My family loved it. Will definitely be making this dish again!!!!

country:
None
text:
This dish came out great and my family loved it. I did cook the sauce on top of the stove for 15 minutes and thickened it with cornstarch as others suggested. I also seasoned the chicken with garlic powder, ginger, onion powder and a tiny bit of Lawry's seasoning salt. Since this recipe has soy sauce which is pretty salty I used very little of the seasoning salt. I baked for 1 hour covered and then 15 minutes uncovered. The chicken carmalized beautifully.

text:
I made this based on the recipe changes in the helpful reviews listed below it (3/4 c ketchup, 3/4 c. honey, 1/2 c. soy mixed together and cooked on the stovetop first ) and it was FANTASTIC! I used boneless skinless chicken thighs and they were perfectly done in about 40 minutes so you can use any pieces of chicken, just adjust the cooking time. I am saving this recipe for my next party or the next time I have to bring a potluck dish because it is SO EASY and delicious! It is very rare for me to find a dish that everyone in my house loves especially the picky kiddos but this passed the test! I served it with smashed potatoes and steamed green beans. Yum!

Display Name:
billymj52

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
made this the other night and the family enjoyed it. very easy to make. I cooked the sauce in a pan on top of the stove to  start to thicken while the chicken was starting to cook in the oven. Then poured it on the chicken when it cooked for a few minutes.  It never truly thickened until I was cleaning up and everything was completely cooled.. The sauce was very thick then. So here is my idea on why the sauce stays  thin when hot - when the honey is hot/warm it is very liquid - when it cools down it thickens, thus a thick sauce. don't let this stop you from trying.

Made it...very good, sweet and savoury.   A few modifications and I used chicken legs with backs instead of wings.   Took previous review suggestions to boil and reduce sauce before pouring over meat.  Made changes to the sauce, instead...used 1/2 cup ketchup, 3/4 honey, doubled garlic, added tsp Thai Chili sauce for bit of heat and teaspoon of lemon juice for bit of tang to cut the sweetness.  I had other stuff in 400f oven so I added it to cook uncovered for 40 minutes.  Basted it every 15 minutes and at end, let rest about 10 minutes.  Chicken was very tender and flavourful.  Sauce was excellent over steamed rice.  Will definitely do this again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-08T08:23:21.083

text:
First off let me clear up that this recipe is from 365 ways to cook chicken and it is the best chicken cookbook ever! 2nd....Sprinkle the wings liberally with pepper, split the wings and don't overlap the chicken when laying in the pan. If you increase the amount of ketchup and garlic and cooked until bubbly and brown, the wings fall off the bone and taste delicious!  I have made this recipe for at least 20 years! I also baste with a turkey baster while cooking.

Made this with boneless skinless breast fillets. I also did not have enough honey. Used molasses and everything turned out great. Followed advice of others and cooked the sauce to a boil. I poured it over the fillets after I cut them up into bite size pieces. I baked at 400 degrees first. I then lowered to 385 degrees. Got the color I wanted and the taste. text:
Very tasty with easy recipe.  Had all ingredients on hand. I added 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of honey, along with 2 tbls red pepper.  Also, I added 1Tbls of  flour to mixture as suggested and boiled on stove all ingredients 10 minutes.  Poured ingredients onto boneless,  skinless thighs and baked uncovered for 45 minutes.  Really good. Adding flour and boiling on stove top was key (I think) to having thicker glaze. Will share recipe and definitely cook again.

country:

text:
I used boneless, skinless chicken breast. The sauce did caramelize for me without cooking it on the stove top, but with 2 tbsp. potato starch (that is what I have, but corn starch should work just as well). As suggested by others, I baked the chicken in the over at 400F until almost done (maybe 20-30 min.), then poured the sauce on it and placed back in the oven. In about 10 min. the sauce had thickened. I mixed the chicken to coat it well and placed back for maybe 5 min. It is delicious and much better than a store bought sauce.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6115133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a lazy cook, so I don't really measure ingredients for recipes like this, but I went easy on the honey and soy, didn't add salt, and used a package of chicken legs. Lined the pan with foil- sprayed with canola oil, and turned chicken twice during cooking, swirling it around in the sauce. Also added red pepper flakes and tabasco and used garlic olive oil and confit garlic (leftover from flavoring the olive oil) instead of fresh garlic. It came out nice and sticky, spicy and sweet! Make sure your sides are done when the chicken comes out, or you'll be tempted to scarf it down beforehand- like I did! Leave the skin on, as others have said (not my normal thing). Took just over an hour. Have also made this with thighs.

text:
I tried this with a few alterations and it came out delicious! I was mixing the ingredients when I realized I didn't have any honey. Having to improvised, I used some pancake syrup. I also used lower sodium soy sauce, and I didn't have enough of that either so I added some apple/cranberry juice.  I used quarter chicken instead of chicken wings. The coating was wonderful, tasted almost like I bar-b-qued it on a grill rather then baked it in my oven. I wouldn't advise anyone to use the apple/cranberry juice as it dulled the taste of the soy sauce a little (maybe pure cranberry juice would have been better), but other then that it was very good!Even with all the alterations.

text:
I didn't think the sauce would carmelize in the oven so I boiled it on the stove with some cornstarch.  It got thick but still not "gooey".  I used drumsticks and basted the chicken every 10 minutes.  I also thought the sauce tasted a little off so I added a tablespoon of bbq sauce and a tbsp of teriyaki sauce as well.  I was still thinking the sauce wasn't very good.  Until the chicken was completely done and the sauce did carmelize at the end.  It ended up delicious!  So, 4 stars for having to make so many changes, but it was a good start.

I love this recipe. I made a couple small changes to it that really seemed to work. I cooked it for 20 minutes and then turned the chicken over. After another 20 minutes I pulled the chicken and finished it on the BBQ for 3-4 minutes on each side. As well, I reserved about 1/4 of the sauce, reduced it stove top and made that into a basting sauce for the BBQ. Fantastic. Did it for a wings competition amongst friends and received positive compliments on it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family and I LOVE the sauce and make the sauce all the time, just to have on hand. It has a semi-teriyaki flavor. I add about 3/4 cup of cool cornstarch water (3 rounded tbsp of cornstarch about) and let it boil again to thicken it. When it heats up or bakes it thins out a lot (even when thickened), so the whole recipe was good, but not very flavorful since the sauce thinned out so much. When using the sauce, I usually add it last to get the full rich flavor, instead of heating it with the food. This recipe goes great with rice too!

text:
This chicken was awesome!  I made it for Sunday dinner and loved it so much, I made it for Sunday dinner the next week.  Unfortunately, I ran out of soy sauce from the first time and used thick soy sauce as a substitute.  I would definitely recommend NOT doing that, as the molasses overtook all other flavors. It was still pretty good though.  I think that the recipe is perfect as is. I could taste a little garlic which blended well with the other flavors.  Also, I'm not a big fan of skin on chicken, but I do like the flavor it gives, so I used chicken drumsticks, and peeled the skin off before I ate it. Delicious!

text:
Wowee what a great meal! This goes really well with some white rice and broccoli. A few suggestions for baking that some may have made before. Boil the sauce and simmer before pouring on the chicken. Baste every 15 minutes or so because the sauce will be a little runny at first. Make sure to turn the chicken. The first time i made this the top of mine burnt because I didn't turn it, so I scraped that off and it was so delicious!!!! Favorite baked chicken recipe I have done after all of the tweaks.

userID:

Display Name:
Connie Marie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5249226.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did this recipe to a T and got the same results as everyone else with lack of caramelization. Then I experimented with the size of the pan. I used legs instead of wings and put fewer pieces into the same size to let the sauce thin on the bottom of the pan. After half of the bake time I took out the pans, flipped the chicken and basted them. But this time the sauce did caramelize. At the end of the bake time I basted one more time to get some extra sauce onto it before serving and it came out wonderfully! I also recommend marinating chicken breasts in the sauce for 20-30 minutes before baking and serving over a bed of rice.

text:
different votes from our house here. My husband and daughter like it "as is". I found it a bit too sweet for me and the next time I made it I added doubled the garlic, added 1 TB of white wine vinegar and 1 TB of lemon juice to cut the sweetness. That version came out more to my liking....the other 2 liked the second version too....more sweet n sour than just sweet....so it all depends on your tastes here. (I had halved the recipe for only 3 of us.....so 2 TB each for a full batch). I also used boneless chicken strips. Wings are too much work for too little meat for me!

text:
this was absolutly wonderful, I put in about 3/4 c ketchup and warmed the sauce on the stove top, I also added 2 tbsp corn starch that i mixed with about 1/3 c. cold water but I added that to the sauce about 1 min. before it was done cooking on the stove top, I also used chicken legs, cooked the chicken in the oven covered for 40 min. pulled it out poured on sauce (reserving about 3/4 c) and baked it in oven for 10 more min. then added the rest of sauce and placed it under broiler on low for 2-3 min. comes out perfect, very tender & tasty, and not extremely sweet

text:
I was so excited to make this dish because of all the great reviews. I thought it was ok, but there are several factors that could have affected why. I used low sodium soy sauce so the flavor wasn't "over powered" by soy sauce flavor like other reviewers said. Also, I'm pregnant so my taste buds are different.  However, I have to add that I was really craving chicken legs tonight and they DID hit the spot. My husband is not a huge soy sauce fan so I made half the chicken with regular BBQ sauce, and honestly I liked those better! I used the reviewer's suggestion in boiling the soy sauce mixture before and adding corn starch to thicken it and it worked great. The legs were very juicy because I left the skin on (but didn't eat it) with both sauces so overall, this recipe's technique was great. I just personally prefered the BBQ sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved the taste of this sauce! It was perfect! I followed the suggestion of a reviewer who said to use 3/4 cup ketchup, 3/4 cup honey, 3-4 garlic cloves, & I also added about 1 1/2 tsp of cornstarch. I brought the sauce to a boil on the stove which thickened it up quite a bit, then I let it rest for a bit. but I think I will still add a little bit more cornstarch to the sauce next time. Someone else said to use 2 tbsps. I also think I'll add half of the sauce to the chicken & halfway through I'll add the rest of the sauce, maybe that'll help thicken it up a little more. I will definitely make this again! Everyone loved it, even though it wasn't as thick as I'd like it to be.

We liked these, but the sauce was a bit thin, and I would have liked it to coat the chicken more. city:

country:

text:
i made this last night with boneless skinless chicken breasts. the 1/2 cup soy sauce was a little too salty for me, so i used only about a 1/4. per other reviews, i baked in the oven on 350 for about 40 minutes and it was good. made again tonight for others, and was great! here's what i did : used the left over sauce from last night to marinade the breasts (butterflied) for about an hour. put the rest in a sauce pan, added more ingredients, and let it simmer and thicken up. i continued to baste the chicken throughout the baking. i was making side dishes that cooked on 450 and wanted to do it all together. so i baked the chicken on 400 for about an hour, then turned it down to 350 for about 20 minutes. it was tender and moist throughout. a definite do again!

text:
This wasn't bad if you like baked chicken.  I followed others' reviews and cooked the sauce on the stove first for a while on low.  I did a pan of wings (as the recipe suggests) and a pan of chicken breasts. To me, the wings were a 4.5 and the breasts were a 3.  The breasts were too dry.  The sauce did caramelize a bit better on the breasts though.  Either way, I will likely make this recipe again, but it won't be a weekly (or even monthly) occurrence.  Occasionally, it's a nice change. :) I'd give it a 4.5 if I could.

text:
This was really good!  I made it on the fly when I had nothing in the house to make for dinner.  This recipe's ingredients are perfect for that!  I improvised to taste (I put lots more garlic in!) and put it all with some sliced carrots in a pot and brought to boil then turned down heat and cooked as recommended or 10 minutes.  I sliced two chicken breasts in long slices and put in a casserole dish and poured the sauce and carrots on top.  I baked at 400 degrees or 20 minutes.  Made plenty of rice to go with it!  It was delicious!  I went from having nothing to make for dinner to being absolutely stuffed!  Can't wait to try more veggied next time (celery, mushrooms, onions, snap peas, peppers, etc)!

text:
I didn't care for this recipe. The sauce had an odd aroma. The taste too is kinda odd, can't really explain how, just odd.  We still ate it as it wasn't too bad, I just won't be making it again.  One side note; I cooked at 350 for exactly an hour and the meat was perfect, tender & moist. If you're going to cook it at 375 I suggest only 45 minutes as it may be overdone if cooked for an hour. I love baked chicken w/sauce recipes that I can serve over rice with veggies, but unfortunately this one will not stay in my box.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, I did the same as others suggested by cooking sauce on stove top first, and it still did not caramelize. It was tasty, but just more like a sweet barbecue sauce. A friend of mine who is a chef said that the reason for this is that honey melts, it does not caramelize. You must have sugar for it to caramelize. Still, was tasty. Definitely season your chicken breasts first and cook them without sauce for about ten minutes; gives the chicken itself more flavor. I am not opposed to making this again, but I guess I will hunt for another recipe for "caramelized" chicken.

text:
Used a mixture of chic breasts and legs. I used the method of making the sauce on the stove top as directed on the front page (most helpful reviews). This was good, but I think my oven was too quick/powerful for this?? the chicken was fully cooked at 35 mins and was burnt, there was smoke billowing out of my oven. I briefly (5-7mins?) turned my back to the oven to prepare mashed potatoes and veggies. It was the sauce at the bottom of the pan that was burnt in particular, the chicken was still edible. While making the chicken before the burning part, I kept checking it every 5 mins and spooning the pool of sauce at the bottom of the pan on top of the chicken. Nobody particularly enjoyed this in my family, everyone thought it was okay/passable. Maybe I will try making this on a lower heat next time since I liked the idea of using common household ingredients.

text:
This was great, although I did a few things differently.  I lightly seasoned my chicken and let it bake in the oven for about 10 minutes so the seasoning would stick and wouldn’t come off once I added the sauce.  I took the advice of the other reviewers and warmed the sauce on the stove and added a couple tablespoons of cornstarch dissolved in a little bit of water. About halfway through I flipped the chicken over so it would absorb more of the sauce. Delicious!!

text:
This is tasty!  I did as other reviewers and heated the sauce on the stovetop before putting everything in the oven.  I also added some Thai chili sauce and corn starch.  With the starch, the sauce was still very runny (and lots of it!), and the chicken sort of "boiled" in the sauce.  So I removed the wings and placed them on a baking sheet and cooked them separately for about 10 minutes and they were perfect!  I had enough sauce left over to freeze for another time.  I'll cut it in half next time.

text:
Very easy to make. Took the wings straight out of the freezer and didn't have the time to let it thaw so squeezed a whole lime in water and soaked it for about 10 minutes. After I rinsed it and added green seasoning sauce, onion and seasoned salt and let it sit for a few minutes. Wings did carmelize and had a great flavour but since I don't like wings I didn't really enjoy it. Maybe next time I'll try drumsticks. My boyfriend loved it. He said if he didn't know i cooked it he would have thought it was restaurant bought.

When making this recipe, I first decided to heat the sauce on the stove to get the ingredients to come together.  I only had a half cup of honey, so for the rest I substituted corn syrup.  I marinated the chicken (I used large breats instead) for an hour or so and then baked at 375.  It took around 30-35 minutes for the chicken to cook and it came out great.  I only wish the sauce would have been thicker, but overall, everyone loved the chicken.  Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor of the chicken with this sauce is great!  I cut up boneless, skinless breasts into bite size pieces and marinated it for a few hours in some of the sauce (stuck the rest of the sauce in the refrigerator).  I dumped the chicken along with the sauce it was marinating in into a pan and cooked it with the lid on, almost like poaching the chicken pieces in the marinade.  When it was cooked thru I added the rest of the sauce to the pan and cooked it for a little longer.  The chicken was great, but the sauce part was very liquidy/runny.  I would probably add a little cornstarch to the extra sauce before adding it to the pan the next time.  We served it over rice and really liked it.

text:
I'd first like to thank all the previous reviewers that totally helped me out with this recipe! I cut the recipe in half & simmered the sauce on the stovetop for 15 min. I baked the chicken at 375 for about an hour, turning it over halfway. Next time I'll baste the chicken more often. Chicken came out very moist & delicious. I also added some dried diced onion to the suace & left out any additional salt seasoning since the soy sauce took care of that flavor! Excellent recipe; thanks so much!

The flavor was great, but my sauce was like water! I removed the wings to a bowl with a slotted spoon, then let the sauce continue to bake for another 30 minutes, then poured it over the chicken. text:
This chicken was easy but the end result was just ok.  I was only able to use boneless chicken breasts, they turned out very tender and juicy but I didn't care for the sweetness.  This chicken was reminiscent of pineapple chicken without the pineapple, it was a little too sweet and kind of fruity tasting, despite adding other things to cut back on that.  Although it was easy, I'm going to pass on this one and consider making the bourbon chicken recipe instead.

text:
Two of my four kids and I LOVED the flavor of this sauce.  It reminds me of the bourbon chicken served at mall food court chinese restaurants.  My husband said it was passable and my other two kids are just too stubborn and picky to try or accept anything new.  I used boneless breasts and decreased the cooking time by half so the sauce wasn't carmelized when the chicken was done.  I just transferred it to a sauce pan and thickened it with cornstarch then poured it back over the chicken.  We poured the spare sauce over our rice.  It was DELICIOUS!

text:
I was suprised at the great reviews.  I made the recipe last night as mentioned except that I used legs.  I had no problems, as others reported, with the carmelizing. Although my boyfriend and I ate the dish for dinner I wouldn't make this again.  I found the taste too strong, almost tasted burnt. I did leave the chicken in the oven for an hour and it looked great but the taste of the glaze is awful, edible but not worth making. I did rub the chicken with salt and pepper before adding the glaze and it wasn't too salty as others mentioned. I may attempt to make this again but using teriyaki, instead of soy sauce, as one of the other reviewers mentioned. It wasn't salty but had a strange taste.

text:
After reading the other member reviews I was very excited when the chicken DID caramelise!! I baked for about an hour on the lowest shelf, just above the oven's heating element. I also basted 3-4 times during cooking and added some chopped caramelised onion to the sauce to thicken. Very yummy, quite sweet, try adding some extra soy and more garlic.

text:
I have made this a couple times the sauce never carmelized.  It didn't really matter, b/c the chicken still tasted good even though it was messy.  This time, I decided to follow another users advice and marinate the chicken wings overnight and then bake them the next day at 350 for 40 minutes on one side, and 275 for another 25 minutes on the other side.  Of all the times I have made this, this way tasted the best and the sauce actually carmelized.  From now on, this is the way I am going to make it.

text:
The flavor is definitely good but the sauce never caramelized and it was a bit too greasy for our tastes.  Next time I make it, I will only use 1/2 cup of honey, add more garlic and pepper, leave out the oil and salt, skin the chicken (using thighs and drumsticks), and add some ginger and lemon juice.  My family loved it and my 4 yr old son is quite picky.  He asked me to make it again the next day!!

This was wonderful! I only had about 2 tbs of soy sauce so I mixed in 2 tbs of honey teriyaki barbeque sauce and a bit more honey.
then I mixed up some extra honey and the barbeque sauce to brush on a bit before cooking was done....I also removed the liquid from the pan about 15 minutes before the end, like suggested, to aid in carmelization... I think it really helped.... 
all in all, it was wonderfully flavorful and moist... we all enjoyed it! Thank you!

country:
None
text:
LOVED his recipe even though we changed it a little. We added pineapple near the end of the baking time, and while preparing it, we added a lot more garlic clove, 2 green onions and a 1/2 lemon squeezed over the chicken. We also added a little sesame oil with the soy sauce, and DID not put any salt in it because of the soy sauce already having that salty taste. This is great over rice or noodles and we used skinless chicken pieces. You can't go wrong with this recipe, although it never carmelized for us (could be all the changes we made) it is easy to make, fast to cook, and DELICIOUS! My son who is not a big fan of meat liked it. Definitley will make this again! Thanks!

text:
I used fresh bone-in chicken thighs and turned them 2 times while baking to coat the chicken as much as possible. The mixture did not carmelize as I hoped it would and remained thin like water however enough of the mixture was on the chicken to give it great taste and color. I prepared steamed white rice on the side; placed the chicken on a serving platter and served the remaining mixture in a serving bowl. The mixture was great on the rice. This recipe is really delicous. I will prepare this dish again for my family.

My husband and I made this and we accidently put in 1 cup of soy sauce instead of 1/2 cup.  Of course it didn't carmelize, but it was great anyway.  We loved it and so did our guests.  Now we'll have to try it with the right recipe!
